texts.definition: The action of moving game elements in game worlds.
markups: <style="Definition">The action of moving game elements in game worlds.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> of game elements is a common activity in games that have game worlds or game boards. It allows players to try and move game elements into favorable positions as well as control or explore game areas. In computer-based games it can give players feelings of speed and vertigo.

With the exception of the value of kings and the ability of pawns to become queens, different <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> abilities are what distinguish different types of pieces in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style>.

The early computer-based games <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Spacewar!">Spacewar!</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style> both allow players to move spaceships by rotation and thrust in the spaceships' direction. However, they also allow players to escape dangerous situations by providing a limited number of hyperjumps that placed the spaceship in a random location. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elite%20series">Elite series</link></style> does the same but in three-dimensional space.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Racing%20Games">Racing Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Need%20for%20Speed%20series">Need for Speed series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gran%20Turismo%20series">Gran Turismo series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/F-Zero%20series">F-Zero series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mario%20Kart%20series">Mario Kart series</link></style> all have movement as the primary activity in the game. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Formula%20D">Formula D</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sokoban">Sokoban</link></style> are also based around <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> but as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Team-based%20Games">Team-based Games</link></style> the challenges in these cases are based upon problem solving and anticipating other players moves. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Advanced%20Squad%20Leader">Advanced Squad Leader</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style> are examples of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Wargames">Wargames</link></style> where <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> in vital in winning but where the <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> is influence by various environmental effects. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/High%20Frontier">High Frontier</link></style> requires careful consideration about interactions between engine thrust, fuel consumption, and rocket mass to explore and colonize the solar system. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cogs">Cogs</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zoo%20Keeper">Zoo Keeper</link></style> are examples that require <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> to solve puzzles but players have to do so under time pressure.

Navigating game worlds in the Super Mario series is a large part of gameplay, and through executing combos additional types of movement can be done. Some of these, e.g. Double Jumping, have found their way into many other games, e.g. Robot Unicorn Attack and being able to be done by scouts in Team Fortress 2. Movement is also important in Another World but in some cases this take the shape of players having to do actions as a rhythmic sequences; the entire gameplay of the Dragon's Lair series is constructed in this fashion.

<style="Link"><link="massively-single-player-online-games">Massively Single-Player Online Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombie%20Lane">Zombie Lane</link></style> have a particular form of <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> in that players can visit each other's gameplay areas to help them with various chores.

<style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> is introduced into games to allow goals such as <style="Link"><link="alignment">Alignment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enclosure">Enclosure</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals as well as activities such as <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> and making <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> easier (through <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> it also makes <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style> possible). However, deciding how game elements can perform <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> depends on how <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> have been created and the intended differences between game elements. <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>,  <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="galleries">Galleries</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="laning">Laning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> all modulate <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> and most of these can be used as the starting points for various designs of <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style> and thereby create <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> are <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that also modulate <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> since players can make use of them to get a form of <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>; <style="Link"><link="vehicle-sections">Vehicle Sections</link></style> can be created to make the use of <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> preferable or even make it a requirement. <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> can also be used to access <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> by doing a more or less complex combination of basic actions. Even so, the easiest form of <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> for one game element compared to other game elements is the ability to move faster as a form of <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Ability</link></style>, and game designs can make use of this to provide <style="Link"><link="dynamic-difficulty-adjustment">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</link></style> regarding <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style>. <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> can indirectly modulate <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> by opening or closing possible routes depending on what space needs to be traveled through. <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> can be used to limit <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> to individual <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> until they are completed; <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> can do likewise but can also be used to make actual gameplay actions related to <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> unnecessary.

The difficulty of <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> is connected to the complexity of the movement and the different ways one can move. The more degrees of freedom of movement a player has, up to the maximum of six (three absolute and three rotational), the more the complexity of the <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> is increased. Further complications to <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> occur through the introduction of acceleration, deceleration, momentum, turn radii, dislocated centers of gravity, articulated vehicles, fuel <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>, and vehicles with complex forms of locomotion. <style="Link"><link="zone-control">Zone of Control</link></style> can hinder och slow <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> in proximity to other game elements. <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style> can be influenced how players move by making quick <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> ruin their chances of succeeding with <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> actions, but reversely aiming systems can require players to be stationary. These various options, and the way <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> are constructed, can be used to create both <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, but this can be further refined in computer-based games through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player/System%20Action%20Composites">Player/System Action Composites</link></style> in which the computer helps calculating routes or providing <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> of the relevant factors.

In <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style>, typical ways of instantiating <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> is having a movement cost to enter an area and using <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> (most often in the form of <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, or a combination of both to determine how many points players have to spend. While simply having a cost of one for each area enter (as e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monopoly">Monopoly</link></style> does) having other costs can be motivated based on <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> in the areas. In <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> is often directly matches to physical buttons but can also be the diegetic effect of successfully performing <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style> (examples of this can be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Another%20World">Another World</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon's%20Lair%20series">Dragon's Lair series</link></style>).

Quick Returns and Quick Travel are ways to avoid having to do Movement though parts of Game Worlds one has already traversed and can thereby remove Movement which could be perceived as Excise. In contrast, Setback Penalties force players to traverse the same parts again as the consequence of failing some challenge. One-Way Travel and other types of Conditional Passageways can be used to guarantee that gameplay progresses in a certain order but not necessarily influence the speed of that progression; they can also be used to to make Movement from one part of the game to the other easy but returning difficult. While Warp Zones may change Game Worlds by making parts topological neighbors and thereby modulate Movement, when players can create the Warp Zones themselves (as for example when reading a portal scroll in Torchlight) this can instead be viewed as making Movement possible. Visits are similar but used in Massively Single-Player Online Games such as CityVille and Zombie Lane to let players go to each other's areas to help with tasks. An non-diegetic form of Movement, but possibly the origins of Movement in games, is the use of Score Tracks.

<style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> can be made to leave <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> to help <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> goals through providing <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style> can help in goals related to <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> both by aiding <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> and by being able to double as <style="Link"><link="save-points">Save Points</link></style>.

One variation of the <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> pattern is to require actual player <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> rather than that of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style>; one way of doing this is through requiring <style="Link"><link="physical-navigation">Physical Navigation</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> is one of the most common <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> found in games, and is a basic way of creating <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> in games and both affects the <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> given the ability to move and the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> they can move within. It is a prerequisite for many actions and goals, e.g. <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> as well as modulating how <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> can be done. It created <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals when it can be used to move <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> to avoid <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> can also be an effect of <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> when this supports other game elements being pushed around. While all intentional <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> requires <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> when this is supported through <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style> showing intermediate target locations, the <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> done to reach these makes them act as <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style>. As soon as players need to consider their own acceleration or speed, or the movement of other game elements, <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> requires <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> does not always offer <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Spatial%20Engrossment">Spatial Engrossment</link></style> but is more likely to do so in <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> since this makes the <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> into <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style>. In contrast, <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> in <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> can give rise to <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>, e.g. games that require players to move between many interconnected places give rise to Traveling Salesman's problems (see <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sokoban">Sokoban</link></style> for two <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> that can create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Spatial%20Engrossment">Spatial Engrossment</link></style> due to focusing completely on <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style>). <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> (and through that also <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>) regarding <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> can also occur in any game where <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> is used to succeed with goals to <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> something. <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> that needs to be done and doesn't offer challenges or choices can be perceived as <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style>, especially if done over already familiar spaces (the use of <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> can mitigate this to some degree while <style="Link"><link="quick-travel">Quick Travel</link></style> can remove it completely).

<style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> of game elements, e.g. <style="Link"><link="moveable-tiles">Moveable Tiles</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, that are not under the control of any players are can be examples of <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> that require <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> or <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style> from the players in response, for example to avoid <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> or to be able to complete <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> actions. The same can be the case when the players' own <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> have forced <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> (see for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zaxxon">Zaxxon</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="moveable-tiles">Moveable Tiles</link></style> can, as in many of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Portal%20series">Portal series</link></style>, be used to offer players specific ways of moving which they may have more or less control over.

When players' <style="CurrentLink">Movement</style> depend on <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> (as for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Snakes%20and%20Ladders">Snakes and Ladders</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monopoly">Monopoly</link></style>), questions of <style="Link"><link="luck">Luck</link></style> affecting gameplay can easily occur and even more so when <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style> are present.

<style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="alignment">Alignment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="physical-navigation">Physical Navigation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player/System%20Action%20Composites">Player/System Action Composites</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="quick-travel">Quick Travel</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="setback-penalties">Setback Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vehicle-sections">Vehicle Sections</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="visits">Visits</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="zone-control">Zone of Control</link></style>
